
Here is a script for you to update `persistent_peers` setting in `config.toml`. Stale peers can cause node inefficiency over time, so the script below selects a few random live peers.

```bash
PEERS=f8ff1443b163e185e8e8b13bb5f9a6384a9f9667@62.171.153.225:16456,6af99da7ee399b571034a4769c344fcb6bdeb8a6@84.247.191.203:26656,1912968bc4056a739c7a4c94f754c1d8ddb9feac@149.50.96.112:26656,553ca3287a4792032136035fa8c711fa75079a73@64.44.171.222:26656,9f1e8680d325b97f9de7197efcdaea9cc8d53088@37.27.43.194:26656
sed -i.bak -e "s/^persistent_peers *=.*/persistent_peers = \"$PEERS\"/" ~/.evmosd/config/config.toml

sudo systemctl restart 0g.service
sudo journalctl -fu 0g.service --no-hostname -o cat
```

## Our peer for ZeroGravity
When you state-sync, you might also consider adding [NODERS]TEAM state-sync peer to your persistent_peers setting in `config.toml`.

```bash
3e2f5e57e0f8eb4475982a08e39e76629731ce7d@og-t-rpc.noders.services:29656
```
